/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%201.jpeg: Dominic, Nick, and Gretta arrive in Bethel, Connecticut, visiting Nick's twin sister, Anya.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Already behind schedule, we are in and out of Bethel lickety split, leaving later that night.
Dominic poses with his 1983 Mercedes wagon. After honing the system while driving across the country, his wagon is now running reliably on veggie oil.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%204.jpeg: After pilfering cooking oil from behind a restaurant, we use thrifted t-shirts as part of our on-the-go filter system. This batch comes from Olive Garden, a pristine source compared to hamburger joints.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%206.jpeg: Filtered cooking oil is lifted up to the roof, then emptied into the auxiliary fuel tank.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: After a few days of round-the-clock driving, we arrive in Glendale, Nova Scotia, the launch point for our bike trip.
Friends of friends Frank and Dolores have kindly offered us a place to stay. With a full kitchen at our disposal, we dine!
All packed, we pose with our bikes before beginning our journey in earnest.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2012.jpeg: Scenery on our first day of riding. Idyllic, no?
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2014.jpeg: For us southwesterners, the water and wildflowers are a sight to behold.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Not far into our journey, various bike problems emerge. On day 2, Dominic has a bulging tube. Here, we reinforce it by wrapping paper around it, a low-tech but age old trick.
Clearly, the paper wasn't strong enough. The explosion has nearly severed this tube in half. Our other spare tubes have undergone similarly ill fates and we are now stuck.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2024.jpeg: Slowed down by maintenance issues, we take a side road to search for a camp spot.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2031.jpeg: Camped by a lake, the rain comes as we ponder how to address our tube + tire problems.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Our first idea: a surgical approach to fixing a tube with a faulty valve stem.
It works! But not for very long, as the tire fails again before we can get far out of camp.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2030.jpeg: What to do now? Bikes are strewn around in apparent chaos, but there is a plan!
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2032.jpeg: A tandem bike is built to get around having only 3 functioning wheels for two bikes. The machine is propellable, but with 2 pivot points, the immutable laws of physics make steering this machine exceedingly difficult.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: We make friends with a local who lives back up on the highway, and he is kind enough to haul us into Sydney, a town big enough to have a bike shop.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2036.jpeg: Looking for extra warmth after days of cold temps and summer rain, we visit a thrift store. Nick performs surgery on a fleece...
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: After altering fleece jacket sleeves, Nick dons homemade knee warmers. On our $10/person/day all-inclusive budget, this type of frugality was a necessity.
Gretta, an excellent fiddle player, tries her hand at Sydney's giant fiddle, built just a few years ago, in 2005.
Camping outside a friendly resident's house in North Sydney, we warm ourselves by the fire, readying for a new chapter in the morning.
With to-go pizza ordered dangerously last minute, we all manage to make it aboard the ferry. (If Gretta looks grumpy, it's probably bc she wants to eat it!!)
Dominic bids farewell to Nova Scotia as we embark on the journey to Newfoundland.
Pizza, then cards, keep us entertained on the 7-hour ferry ride.
Gretta and Dominic deliver icy stares at the drubbing administered by Nick.
Arriving at Channel-Port aux Basques (Newfoundland) at 11:30pm, we camp outside town and bid adieu the next morning.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2052.jpeg: Dominic freshens up in a lake along our bike ride.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: A few tuneups—nothing former bike mechanic Dominic can't handle—and we're humming along in Newfoundland.
Sunny weather in Newfoundland makes for a surprisingly auspicious start to our experience in this province.
Dusk sets in late, after a gloriously hassle-free day of real riding—the first in quite some time!
Camping again. A beautiful photo, though one altered by the camera settings to add yellow.

Aaron, a friend we "brought home from the (gas) bar" (what they call gas stations), poses for a photo. Gas stations seem to be central gathering points in the vast expanse of Newfoundland, cut through by the singular Trans Canadian Highway.
We rose to see Aaron off at the disciplined but ungodly hour of 6am, claiming to be right behind him. But by 7am, Dominic wants a nap.
Gretta gears up for the day with a hit of maple syrup.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2060.jpeg: Heated up and ready to ride a few minutes later, she tries to wrestle Dominic out of his stupor.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: But Dominic gets the best of her.
Our first big town in Newfoundland, Corner Brook (pop. 20K), provides opportunity and a nice spot to make camp.
The next day, we indulge, sleeping in and reading.
Laying in the sun, lovebirds Dominic and Gretta find a way to snuggle and read at the same time.
Dominic and Gretta saunter off the grassy dance floor at a local festival in Corner Brook.
We finally meet up with Ryan, a couchsurfer connection who provides us with room for our remaining time in C.B.
We just have to point out all the berries we found along the way. Strawberries here!
Wild raspberries!
Tart cherries!
With the cherries eventually making a delicious syrup for our pancakes.
Woody Point lighthouse was iconic.
Pink clouds cover the bay as we set camp.
After a lovely night of camping, we bid farewell to Woody Point. With barely enough room for our bikes, the water taxi takes us across the bay to Norris Point.
/media/Map%20with%20Arrows.jpeg: Ferries connect various points on this map of Newfoundland. (Part of our secret plan to make a loop.)
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%2099.jpeg: Gorgeous sunset at our camp site, right on the water.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20108.jpeg: At Arches Provincial Park, Dominic adds some challenge to the short hike.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20114.jpeg: A human arch mirrors the earthen arch below.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20121.jpeg: Have you ever camped on a peat bog? It's sooo sooooooffft.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20102.jpeg: Pitcher plants abounded in this rocky, peaty terrain.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20101.jpeg: This pitcher plant has some food to digest.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20122.jpeg: It wasn't safe to get much closer to this massive moose.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20103.jpeg: A bird alights on Dominic's hand.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: With discontinued ferries thwarting our loop dreams, we head south. This time, we give Gros Morne its due. The sign showing a man climbing a sheer rock face was an exaggeration, but not by much.
The 7-hr round trip hike to Gros Morne peak started in the woods but later turned into a steep and seemingly endless scramble.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20124.jpeg: Our primary cooking device, a space efficient pressure cooker.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Dominic, eating in style.
Loading up the pressure cooker.
Another dish, which may not look appetizing, but was assuredly delicious.
Popcorn!? Yes, we were living in style.
With a real oven in Corner Brook, we could make shepherd's pie, a delicious and vegan treat for our host Ryan.
After a night back with Ryan in Corner Brook, we are treated to Toutons, doughy biscuits fried and then drizzled in molasses. A Newfie specialty!
Splitting off from the Trans-Can. Hwy, we headed down the road towards Burgeo, a 150-km isolated stretch.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20140.jpeg: Lakes kept us cool along the way. Here's the vantage point over one.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: After 2 days on this isolated road, and 3 since our last town, we found the coastal terminus, Burgeo (pop. 1,700), to be a welcome sight.
After taking the ferry to Ramea, an island town (pop. 462) southeast of Burgeo, we meet with friends and then climb Man o' War Hill.
We feast that night with Jim and Judie, folks we'd been communicating with on couchsurfing.com prior to arriving on the island of Ramea.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20115.jpeg: On an early stretch in Newfoundland, one of Nick's spokes sheared in two when his pannier flew into his wheel--a result of poor strap design and uneven Newfie roads.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20120.jpeg: We sewed and sealed the bag with shoe goo.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20117.jpeg: Frank's Badass Bailing Wire was used to reconnect the broken spoke into one piece.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Nick's rebuilts his rear axle in Ramea, which unbeknownst to us had fractured at some point earlier.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20155.jpeg: Ferrying west, we arrive at Grand Bruit, a fishing town and outport community only reachable by boat. With a year round population that has dwindled to under 15, the residents have been grappling for years with the specter—or as some would call it, "opportunity"—of Resettlement.
/geotagged2/Nova_Newfie%20-%20153.jpeg: On GB's 4-foot wide roads, this very good boy has picked out the largest stick possible for a game of fetch. When evening sets in, locals offer us the use of the main dock outbuilding for shelter, and we are happy to oblige.
/geotagged/Newfoundland%20and%20Nova%20S: Back in Channel-Port aux Basques, we splurge, making pizza-on-the-ferry a tradition for the boat ride back to Nova Scotia. Yum.
After a day of biking in Nova Scotia, night brings our familiar foe: incessant rain. By morning, it has rained so hard that Dominic's tent was sopping wet.
Dominic demonstrates how wet his tent had become. (We later found out Gretta was silently weeping much of the night from the cold.)
With rain all night, our once dry camp site is now a shallow bog.
On the bright side, convenient for hand washing.
No need to hunt for a place to wash dishes.
Frank and Dolores' home in Glendale is the terminus of our trip. After harvesting blackberries and apples nearby, we make pie to celebrate.
Posing in front of their house, we bid Frank and Dolores farewell before hitting the road in Dominic's greasemobile.
We extract part of the valve from an exploded tube and insert it through an incision into another tube. After patching the incision, we cross our fingers.
The journey continues, this time up the Great Northern Peninsula.
This was the summit on a relatively "clear" day.
Did we mention we love sunsets?
